metadata.case_name: Watch Ward Employees of Ahmedabad Textile Mills v. Mill Owners

facts.text: The 385 appellants are employees in the Watch Ward Department of various textile mills in Ahmedabad.

Appellants filed 20 applications between July 22, 1953, to October 6, 1953, before the authority under the Payment of Wages Act claiming overtime wages for January 1951 to December 1951 and June-July 1953.
Applications accompanied by 20 applications praying for condonation of delay under second proviso to s.15(2) of Payment of Wages Act.
Authority held appellants failed to prove sufficient cause for not making applications within prescribed period and refused condonation.
Appellants moved High Court at Bombay under Arts. 226 and 227; applications dismissed.
High Court granted certificate under Art. 133 as subject-matter exceeded Rs. 20,000 and raised substantial question of law.
Section 59 of Factories Act, 1948 came into force on September 23, 1948, providing overtime wages to workers; appellants not workers under s.2(1).
Bombay Shops and Establishments Act, 1948 came into force January 11, 1949; appellants employees under s.2(6); s.70 applies s.59 of Factories Act but effect doubtful.
Representative union raised industrial dispute by notice September 20, 1949 (Ref. IC No. 192 of 1949).
Industrial Tribunal award November 25, 1950 assumed Factories Act not applicable, awarded nine-hour day, holidays, limited overtime.

Appellate decision in Ruby Mills case by Chief Judge Court of Small Causes on May 2, 1952 construed s.70 to extend s.59 Factories Act to such employees (Bombay Labour Gazette Jan 1953 Vol.32 No.5 p.521).
Union moved Minister of Labour, Bombay on October 30, 1952 to extend Factories Act benefits.
Minister replied November 1, 1952 drawing factories dept attention to Ruby Mills judgment.
Union secretary requested Chief Inspector of Factories, Ahmedabad to enforce Ruby Mills decision; subsequent correspondence with factory authorities and Mill Owners Association.
Mill Owners Association accepted coverage under Factories Act in May 1953; overtime paid from July 1953 (some from Jan/May 1953).
In August 1953, secretary of new union wrote to employers requesting overtime for prior period; no sympathetic response.
Appellants alleged bona fide belief that Acts did not apply, pursued industrial court diligently; employers conceded entitlement only from May 1953, negotiations failed.
Authority found ignorance of law not sufficient cause; no satisfactory explanation for delay after May 2, 1952 Ruby Mills decision; correspondence showed prospective claims only.
High Court agreed ignorance of law not sufficient cause, distinguished from mistake of law/forum.
Supreme Court decision in B.P. Hira v. C.M. Pradhan on May 8, 1959 resolved doubt on s.70.

legal_issues.text: Whether ignorance of law or mistake of law constitutes 'sufficient cause' under second proviso to s.15(2) of Payment of Wages Act for condoning delay.
Whether appellants explained delay after Ruby Mills decision on May 2, 1952.
Whether showing sufficient cause for initial delay removes bar for subsequent delay under the proviso.

petitioner_arguments.text: Proviso to s.15(2) confers wide judicial discretion not circumscribed; ignorance of law can be sufficient cause, especially in welfare legislation; no rigid rule excluding it.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Hyman v. Rose (1912 A.C. 623); Namdeo Lokman Lodhi v. Narmadabai (1953 S.C.R. 1009); Brij Indar Singh v. Kanshi Ram (1917 L.R. 44 I.A. 218)

petitioner_arguments.text: Once sufficient cause shown for not filing within 6 months, no further limitation; application can be made anytime thereafter.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Lingley v. Thomas Firth (1921 1 K.B. 655); J. Hogan v. Gafur Ramzan; Salamat v. Agent East Indian Railway; Kamarhatti Co. v. Abdul Samad

petitioner_arguments.text: Period until May 2, 1952 covered by ignorance of s.70 effect.

respondent_arguments.text: Ignorance of law not sufficient cause under proviso.
No sufficient or satisfactory reasons for delay after May 2, 1952 Ruby Mills decision; appellants did not specify when they knew, no immediate action, correspondence showed prospective claims.

court_reasoning.text: Authority's finding that no sufficient cause for delay after May 2, 1952 is factual and unchallenged; fatal to claim.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Finding on fact not challengeable in these appeals.

court_reasoning.text: Proviso similar to s.5 Limitation Act; explanation must cover whole delay period.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Ram Narain Joshi v. Parameswar Narain Mehta (1903 I.L.R. 30 Cal. 309)

court_reasoning.text: Argument that initial sufficient cause removes further limitation rejected; proviso prescribes 6 months for application itself, unlike English Workmen's Compensation Act cases where limitation on notice, not proceedings.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distinguishes Lingley (1921 1 K.B. 655), Powell (1900 A.C. 366), Indian Workmen's Compensation Act s.10.

holdings.text: Appellants failed to show sufficient cause for entire delay, particularly after May 2, 1952.
Unnecessary to decide if ignorance of law is sufficient cause.

precedents_cited.relevance: Resolved doubt on effect of s.70 Bombay Shops Act applying s.59 Factories Act.

precedents_cited.citation: Bombay Labour Gazette Jan 1953 Vol.32 No.5 p.521
precedents_cited.relevance: First proper construction of s.70 extending overtime benefits.
Wide construction of discretion against forfeiture.
Wide discretion in relief against forfeiture.

precedents_cited.case_name: Brij Indar Singh v. Kanshi Ram
precedents_cited.relevance: Mistake of law treated as sufficient cause under s.5 Limitation Act in proper cases.

precedents_cited.case_name: Lingley v. Thomas Firth Sons Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Once reasonable cause for claim notice, no further limitation for proceedings; distinguished as limitation here on application.

precedents_cited.case_name: Powell v. The Main Colliery Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Limitation on notice to employer, not tribunal proceedings.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ram Narain Joshi v. Parameswar Narain Mehta
precedents_cited.relevance: Under s.5 Limitation Act, explanation must cover whole delay.
Followed Lingley on Workmen's Compensation Act.

precedents_cited.relevance: Followed Lingley on pre-1938 Workmen's Compensation Act.

precedents_cited.relevance: Obiter on Lingley applicability post-1938 amendment; no attention to amendment.

statutes_cited.relevance: Distinguished on limitation for notice vs. application.

outcome.summary: Appeals dismissed as authority's factual finding of no sufficient cause for delay after May 2, 1952 not challenged; unnecessary to decide if ignorance of law sufficient cause. Preliminary objection on certificate not considered.
outcome.costs: Parties to bear their own costs in this Court.

key_quotes.text: "ignorance of law cannot be said to be a sufficient cause under the relevant proviso."
key_quotes.speaker: lower_court
key_quotes.significance: Authority's holding affirmed by High Court.

key_quotes.text: "the explanation has to cover the whole of the period of delay."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning applying Limitation Act analogy.

key_quotes.text: "This latter conclusion is a finding on a question of fact and its propriety or validity could not have been challenged before the High Court and cannot be questioned before us."
